awd_titl_txt: MLWiNS: Decentralized Heterogeneous Deep Learning for Efficient Wireless Spectrum Monitoring
awd_abstract_narration:
As wireless networks evolve to be increasingly massive and complex, traditional spectrum monitoring methods with model-based signal processing techniques have become inadequate and may even fail to provide accurate wireless network evaluation. Meanwhile, deep learning techniques have been proven successful in standard centralized learning tasks (e.g., image classification), yet it is barely explored for large-scale wireless sensing systems, which entail unconventional node distribution, complex channel fading and user collaboration opportunities. This project develops innovative decentralized heterogeneous deep learning techniques for large-scale wireless systems. The outcomes of this project lead to technical innovations that tackle several major challenges of the state-of-the-art wireless sensing and management systems, including the incapability of conventional sensing and management schemes in ultra-wide wireless spectrum settings, the difficulty in handling heterogeneous tasks and non-IID data with deep learning technologies, as well as the costly overhead of communication and computation in distributed deep learning for large-scale networks.

This project addresses the unique challenges of large-scale wireless spectrum sensing by developing a revolutionary decentralized deep learning framework. Three main thrusts are planned.  In Thrust 1,  major challenges of complex and large-scale wireless spectrum sensing nowadays are investigated, and an innovative deep learning-based solution is developed for practical spectrum sensing tasks. In Thrust 2, dedicated communication and computation schemes are developed to optimize the performance of the proposed decentralized deep learning framework. In Thrust 3, the very first exploratory effort is made to understand and utilize the intricate role of machine learning in spectrum management, based on the key observation that it consumes wireless network resources to bring in added value to network resource utilization. Experimental testing is demonstrated for practical spectrum monitoring applications. The proposed wireless sensing and management system can benefit a plethora of large-scale wireless network systems, such as a 5G wireless network and other large-scale mesh networking systems. The education plan enhances existing curricula and pedagogy by integrating interdisciplinary modules on embedded systems, mobile computing, and machine learning with newly developed teaching practices.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
As wireless networks evolve to even more massive and complex, traditional spectrum monitoring methods with model-based signal processing techniques become inadequate or even fail to pro-vide accurate wireless network evaluation. On the other hand, though deep learning techniques have been proven successful in standard centralized learning tasks (e.g., image classification), it is barely explored for large-scale wireless sensing systems, which involves unconventional node distribution and collaboration and complex channel fading. Through this project, we have investigated the unique challenges of large-scale wireless spectrum sensing and accomplished a revolutionary decentralized deep learning framework. Three comprehensive thrust were performed: In Thrust 1, we investigated the major challenges of complex and large-scale wireless spectrum sensing nowadays and developed an innovative deep learning-based solution for particular spectrum sensing tasks. In Thrust 2, we proposed dedicated communication and computation schemes to optimize the performance of the proposed decentralized deep learning framework. In Thrust 3, we made the very first effort in exploring the intricate role of machine learning in spectrum management when it consumes wireless network resource to bring in added value to resource utilization. We further evaluated the implementation feasibility of the proposed technology with more wireless sensing contexts. Experimental exploration will be demonstrated with particular spectrum monitoring applications.

This project provides valuable resources for the artificial intelligence and wireless sensing and have been published in many top-notch journals and conferences, including IEEE Transactions on Neural Networks and Learning Systems, IEEE Transactions on Wireless Communications, IEEE Internet of Things Journal, the Journal of Machine Learning Research, DAC, ICCAD, WWW, ICC, ICCASP.

The outcomes of this project will lead to technical innovations that tackle several major challenges of the state-of-the-art wireless sensing and management systems, including the incapability of conventional sensing and management schemes in ultra-wide wireless spectrum settings, the difficulty in handling heterogeneous tasks and Non-IID data with deep learning technologies, as well as considerable distributed deep learning communication and computation consumption. The developed theory and mechanisms on wireless and deep learning systems are built on several key ideas for decentralized nodes to collaboratively evaluate the wireless network situation and effectively manage the access with distributed heterogeneous deep learning techniques. The research outcomes have been disseminated through high-quality publications and presentations in well-known conferences. The PIs also gave a few keynote speeches at some well-known conferences and workshops to publicize their latest scientific research results.

From the education perspective, at George Mason University, research training opportunities were offered to three PhD students and one postdoc researcher. Both PIs work closely with these trainees and mentored them jointly. The project also offers research opportunities to an undergraduate student, who published his first conference paper on a topic at the intersection of information theory and multi-user private information retrieval. The PIs also offered research relevant courses, such as AI and wireless network, etc., as well as weekly seminars to both undergraduate and graduate students. Several PhD students are involved in this project as well. The project activities help them better understand the principles of intelligent computer engineering and find their research directions. It is worth mentioning that some PhD students who were partially supported by this project have finished their dissertations and become tenure-track professors right after their graduation.
